page.title: 14PHEASANTS-LITTLE OFFLEY
page.content: The enclosure is enlarged as the chicks get bigger.Pheasants in captivity will badly peck each other,so,when only a few days old the tip of the beak is clipped.At 3 weeks a white 'beak piece'is placed in the nostril of the beak and into the mouth,preventing them from attacking each other.At about 6 weeks they are put into 'release pens',about six to eight feet high,out in the local woods,and it is hoped they will remain in that area during the shooting season. This year's chicks will probably not breed for two years.The loss of chicks raised this year is around three percent. 'Fine weather for Ascot,good year for partridge rearing' Ascot in 1985 was very wet!
